arch:property.oc:show_val: 61.80 m north south, unknown east west.

The West Precinct Wall is one of the major architectural elements of the Upper Temenos, defining the outer boundary of the Temple. This is clearly a massive construction, well built and truly monumental. It represents the first event within the trench’s history, and was the orienting point against which the rest of the features of the trench were eventually built. This wall serves a number of functions, not only as the western wall of the Temple Precinct providing a substantial barrier and divider, but also in the south of the precinct as the east face of the Cistern-Reservoir (see the SP110 report by Martha Sharp Joukowsky, Loci 20 and 31). It appears that this wall was constructed very early in the history of the Temple, during Site Phase I when the general outline of the Great Temple was established. The later Roman and Byzantine construction revealed in Trench 105-106 (as well as in Trench 31), demonstrate a transformation in the function of this wall. The stairs (Locus 72) in the “hypocaust room,” for example, could possibly have extended over the somewhat collapsed West Precinct Wall, allowing a unity of space earlier denied by the wall. Evidence of collapse and repair in the south of the West Precinct Wall (see the SP110 report by MSJ) suggest again that by the time of the Roman and Byzantine construction near the north of the wall, there may have been significant alterations to it. This is demonstrated more concretely by the later ceramic pipe extending along the top of the extant West Precinct Wall (SP110 Locus 7). In Trench 105-106, such alterations are seen in vertical channel cut into the wall (Locus 70) near the entrance to the bathroom. Clearly, this massive wall was an important feature throughout the history of the Temple. Locus 38 is quite damaged in parts, varyingly intact with at most nine courses, and at least four courses. In places it is quite evenly well-laid with nicely dressed sandstone ashlars, while in other places it is unevenly laid using smaller ashlars (sometimes hewn, sometimes unhewn) and snecking stones. There are no clear boundaries between original and repaired parts of the wall, so it has been defined as one uniform wall. It is quite a wide wall, two rows thick. Despite the repairs, the wall is still well made, as can be seen all along the exposed wall. Notably, we have only exposed the west face of the wall and the surface of its top. The east face was exposed in Trench 76 (2000) and Special Project 108 (2005).

Phase I: Preparation: 1st c. BCE quarrying and leveling of the bedrock beneath the Upper Temenos. Some subterranean canalization is installed at this time along with the possible construction of the temple East 'Cistern.' The Sword Deity is carved into the wall of the escarpment south of the precinct.
